Every night on weekdays, my father and sister watch their nightly soap operas. Whenever a "tense" confrontation happens in the show, my father says to me, "This is getting real heavy," Those shows ain't got nothing on this movie. Children of Men has to be one of the most heavy-hearted, if not depressing, films I've seen. 

After the youngest person in an infertile world dies at 18 years old, hope for mankind is lost. Theo Faron (Clive Owen), a lowly office worker from London, is recruited by his ex-wife Julian (Julianne Moore) to get a young Fuji immigrant across borders. Though Britain is one of the only stable nations left in the world, there is an escalating war between the national police and rebels. While reluctant to help Julian with transporting her young Fuji friend, he soon finds out that she is much more important than he thought she was. After a dangerous turn of events, the only key to mankind's salvation is suddenly put in Theo's hands. 

One of the most outstanding things about this film was that it feels similar to a modern action film, even if the theme and mood of the whole film was completely different. The film wonderfully fuses drama and science fiction, set against the backdrop of dystopia mostly in the midst of a war. While most films would unbalance the three different genres, this one executes perfectly. 

One problem I'd have with this film would be the overwhelmingly depressing mood. While I didn't exactly hate the mood entirely, it wouldn't exactly be a film you'd want to watch when feeling down. 

What probably intrigues me about this film the most, was its theme of hope and faith in the face of darkness and despair. It's a theme I usually see in kids' movies, but what those movies lack, and what this film does, is that there aren't any melodramatic overtones. The ending was probably the best scene in the film. There was subtlety and suspense, and there was one part of you that thought that it wasn't gonna end right there. There wasn't going to be any sappiness or sentimentality. There were going to be consequences. *SPOILERS* The final shot of Kee quietly trying to comfort her baby through singing, and Theo slowly sliding into unconsciousness from a possibly fatal gunshot wound was perfect. You wouldn't know if there was going to be a slightly happy ending (because "slightly happy" is all this film is going to get). Is the Human Project real? If they were, are they good guys, or are they just like Luke and his Fishes? Does Theo die? Will Kee's baby actually help mankind? You wouldn't for sure. All these questions cause the suspense. The subtlety comes from the simple long take of a new mother comforting her baby. Once they mixed, everything became perfect. *END OF SPOILERS* Overall, I think this film deserves a 4.5 out of 5 because it lets you take in all the little things (performances, themes), it keeps you glued to the screen, and it lets you care about the characters in a way no ordinary post-apocalyptic drama film can.

Children of Men is, in fact, a masterpiece. It has it all, great direction, compelling script, beyond interesting concept, fantastic acting, and some mesmerizing visuals. It also has this way of making everything in the movie seem baron and cold. Now, this is a dark movie. It's about a pandemic that makes everyone in the world infertile and Clive Owen has to protect the last pregnant women and get her to safety. But the visuals and the cinematography makes everything seem cold and in a way dull...and it is awesome. The best parts of the movie are when they are showing you this world that these people live in. It looks tired in a way and it's all the more interesting.
From the opening sequence you are pulled into this world. It's not post-apocalyptic, but it's close. Here's a SPOILER ALERT so if you want to see this, don't read on. So, the opening shows Clive Owen walking into a coffee shop to buy some coffee. On the television it's saying that the youngest person on earth has just died and everyone in the shop is crying or looking at the TV in disbelief. Owen decides not to stick around and he walks out and walks down the street. Then all of a sudden the coffee shop explodes and it goes to the main title. It's so cool and it really gives you an idea of what you're getting in for.
The rest of the movie is incredible too, but there is one scene that I want to talk about that I thought was phenomenally done. It's near the end after Owen has delivered the baby and after the mother was taken away. Owen finds her by listening to the sound of the baby crying and he gets into an apartment building and outside all hell is breaking lose. London is trying to revolt and the Army started coming and everyone is dying outside and it was tough for Clive Owen to even get to the building. So he gets up there by listening to the baby and when he gets to the floor he sees everyone in the hallway looking down it trying to see if that is actually a baby's cry. All you hear is the baby and the guns outside and Owen walks down there and finds the mother and the baby and leads them out while everyone in the hallway is touching the baby and in complete disbelief. This part is so cool right here. So Owen and the mother are walking down the stairs and the Army barges in and are screaming to like shoot, but when the soldier sees the baby he stops and then screams, "hold you fire!" Then as the two are walking out the soldier's part to two sides and make a path for them. Some soldiers fall to their knees, some are praying, and most of them are just looking at this baby astonished with their mouths gaping. This moment is priceless. Everything is so silent. All you can hear are the gunshots in the distance. It is so cool and it's so incredibly eerie and genuine that it puts you in a state in which you are in utter awe. Then there's an explosion and the place goes quickly back to a state of chaos. 
	This whole movie is like this though. It's so genuine and just so real even though it's a fictional and highly unlikely story. Part of this goes to the actors for their phenomenal jobs throughout the movie and a lot of it goes to the director who created this world with the most finesse and skill. I feel like this is how people would really act during this sort of situation. It would be devastating but this made it look really cool. As I said before, Children of Men is a masterpiece and will go down as a sci-fi classic.

For example there are no fertile women left in the world, but when one woman is revealed to be pregnant, the militant revolutionary group called the Fishes decides that they want the woman's baby to use as a political tool for their coming revolution. How exactly the baby would be any good against the police state, I do not know. But what really left me scratching my head was that Clive Owen's character tells the pregnant woman that she will be killed for her baby. I understand that the only way the Fishes could take the baby away would be to kill the mother, but here's where that looses me: The human race is on the brink of extinction due to infertility and the Fishes actually want to kill the first pregnant woman in years? That really understates how horrible the human condition is when the characters in the film don't even realize it. Also, the film's political correctness is just appalling.

Dystopian futures have been a staple in the movies since Metropolis in 1927. They can range from cutting edge (The Matrix) to ridiculous (Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure). One thing all of them should have in common: they should immerse the audience into the new world they have created. This world is the driving force of Children of Men, a unique take on the future of mankind. Writer/Director Alfonso Curaon crafts a wonderful tale of despair, mystery, heroism, and suspense as Children of Men pushes its hero, Theo (Clive Owen) further into the desolation of a dying Britain. 

A great tragedy has befallen humanity in 2027. The youngest person in the world has just died. He was 18 years old, because humanity has become infertile starting in 2009 (for reasons unknown). Right after the death, Theo unexpectedly gets a call from his ex-wife Julian (Julianne Moore), who is active in a group of rebels fighting the British government. She asks him to escort a group out of Britain to a society called the Human Project. The group includes Julian, Luke (Chiwetel Ejiofor), the leader of the insurrection, Miriam (Pam Ferris), a voodoo worshipper, and Kee (Clare-Hope Ashitey). The reason for the aid of Theo and secrecy is a whopper: Kee is pregnant. Theo must navigate through multiple treacheries including betrayal, power grabs, and lots of weapons. 

From its first scene, Curaon tells you there is something a little off about our current setting. His dying society bears an uncanny resemblance to a war torn Europe post-WW II. The color scheme is destaturated to paint the world in bleak grays. For every LCD billboard there are 10 poor homeless people staring at them. The uniqueness of showcasing a future society as one the audience has seen in the past makes it easier for the audience to understand 2027 Britain as well as provide a terrifying paradox of a future society than cannot advance. This hauting image of a poverty-stricken, urgent, dying society is elevated using a hand-held camera with long unbroken takes. By experiencing the world with the characters instead of above them, Curaon transplants humanizes this lovelorn place and allows the audience to personally feel the character's pain. 

If only Curaon's script could match his setting. Overall, the script is very strong and emotionally competent. There is a violent unexpected attack in the first 5 minutes of the picture, which sets the script up for lots of twists and turns as the story goes along. There are two inherent problems for the story though: The Human Project is a macguffin (for those who don't know, a macguffin is a Hitchcock term describing a plot element providing motivation for a character's actions that is not explained to the audience), and the direction of the story is the path of least resistance. What this means is that the story does not bother explaining the epidemic of infertility or how a new baby will survive in the current setting. Instead, the script focuses on the consequences of the baby ending up with the rebellion or the government. Despite the macguffin, Children of Men's script does a great job of showing character depth and progression while providing some really suspenseful chase sequences and unexpected acts of heroism along the way.

The acting ranges from solid to great. Clive Owen is very good as Theo. The script gives him a haunted past, which he uses to push himself into perpetually more dangerous scenarios. Chiwetel Ejiofor showcases impressive complexity for a character that could have had one note to his personality. Pam Ferris and Clare-Hope Ashitey (in her 2nd role) provide spunk and determination to the story, and Michael Caine (as Theo's hippie friend) and Julianne Moore are always great. The one failing is that the government and rebellion are essentially faceless entities, making their causes unimportant to the central characters.

Children of Men is one of those rare instances where at the end we wish there was more time to explore the consequences of the story. It leaves you with plenty of questions about the fragility of humanity and the unsteady equilibrium of peace the world revolves around. Children of Men could make for a great TV miniseries; until that day, Alfonso Curaon's adaptation of P.D. James's novel is a cautionary tale about the value of human life that won't leave your thoughts very easily.

Children of Men is undoubtedly one of the strongest sci-fi films of the last decade. The story, based on a thought-provoking novel by P.D. James, is very evenly paced and has a certain gripping effect on the viewer, right until the very last minutes. Cinematography is perfectly moody and obscure, making the futuristic London look like a war-infested playground where no one is safe. The film shows how - in difficult, brutal times of infertility - one man tries to save a miraculously pregnant woman from the omnipresent chaos. This man named Theo, firstly a typical bureaucratic non-believer, starts to follow his senses and begins to show his true nature, as the bold and protective man on a dangerous mission towards the rebirth of mankind. The film follows closely all the events up to the climatic moment of an immigrant uprising and the thrilling battle for life and death. The camera movement is greatly exhilarating, and makes the viewer feel as though he is right in the middle of the whole action. The performances are believable, as the actors we see on screen are able to denude all their deepest emotions, bravely exhibiting fear, angst, anxiousness, and even faith in a forthcoming happy ending. Overall, it's truly a violent, heartbreaking, intriguing, full-bodied sci-fi worth watching.

The best thing about this movie is the steady, long shots each scene provides without ever cutting away, making you believe you're right in the passenger seat along for a thrill ride.

As a thriller, the film is blisteringly intense and incredibly effective. From the bomb blast that caps off the opening credits to the frenzied urban warfare sequences that dominate the film's closing thirty minutes, Cauron never lets the film lag. Though it slows down enough to deal with character development and exposition, the film maintains a running intensity as Theo and Kee try to stay one step ahead of terrorists, the police, the army and random opportunists. Several action scenes are shot in continuous takes, and make for compelling and electrifying viewing.However, the film works as a socio-political drama as well. Though Cauron's two central messages (that immigrants enrich, rather than threaten, Western society, and that the outlook for human survival is dim when operatives on all sides let ideology displace compassion and good judgment) are strongly put, he is never so heavy-handed that they dominate or displace the actual storyline. Similarly, while the film makes numerous metaphorical references to present-day events, they are never so contrived as to derail the narrative.The film features solid performances from Clive Owen, who is at his rugged, rumpled best, and Julianne Moore. Supporting players also do well: Michael Caine is terrific as Theo's pot-growing hippie friend, the versatile Chiwitel Ejiofor is again in fine form as a revolutionary cell leader, and Pam Ferris is also good as another of Kee's protectors. It is, however, Claire-Hope Ashitey who stands out as the illegal immigrant who may well be humanity's hope for the future.Children of Men is packed with explosive action, incendiary social commentary and some white-hot performances. As a result, it may well be the best film of the year.

Children of Men is ultimately a sophisticated journey of the triumphs and failures of human nature. Director, Alfronso Cuaron has truly crafted a dark and riveting portrayal of a future with no hope, as all of the world's women have apparently become infertile. In this future, the world isn't much different from today. There are no flying cars, no robots, only dark city landscapes fluttering with litter, rubble, and despair. This future civilization is at its breaking point, and there are two opposing sides depicted in the storyline: A rebel group that is labeled as an extremist terrorist regime by the media, who's stated mission is to deliver a young woman, Kee, to the Human Project, which is a covert organization of some of the world's greatest minds who are collectively searching for a solution for the world's infertility. And then there is the government, which draws many parallels from Nazi Germany in its continuous propaganda on television and the banishment of desperate immigrants into essential exile in slum-like conditions which are fenced, guarded, and separated from the locals. There are many philosophical ideas throughout the entirety of this film; too many begin explaining as that would be an entire subject upon itself. And yes, there does exist some religious references in many parts of the film, some blatantly obvious, and others, metaphorically painted by the masterful strokes of director, Alfronso Cuaron. Surprisingly, Cuaron has knack for action and suspense, as many of the scenes and action sequences unfold with just one continuous camera shot, much like the D-Day invasion scene from Saving Private Ryan. In other words, not only are the action sequences jarring and suspenseful, they're also completely refreshing and unique. That said, (***SPOILER ALERT***) there is one sequence towards the very end of the film, where Theo is guiding Kee and her newborn baby from the deadly shootout between the rebels of the uprising and the military, and suddenly all of the bystanders (exiled immigrants) stand completely still in awe at the sight of this newborn. Gunshots continue to echo in the distance, yet the bystanders gather and pray at the sight of Kee's child. Theo and Kee continue further down the stairs, as they encounter the rebels, holding their guns, and then the soldiers, and to cap-off this utterly breathtaking and emotional scene, the soldiers are ordered to cease-fire at the sight of the baby. This scene is one of the few that I can ever say that brought tears to my eyes. It is very powerful indeed. And much like that scene, Children of Men is a riveting and powerful film, and it is very under appreciated in both its vision and brilliance.

Set in the year 2027, Children Of Men centers around a futuristic dystopia involving human infertility. No woman has been able to become pregnant for almost two decades, leaving humanity in a bitter epoch of despair. Illegal immigrants are rounded up in a totalitarian police state and centered off into refugee camps. Theo Faron (Clive Owen) plays a civil servant who must escort a young refugee woman, Kee (Claire-Hope Ashitey) across the country. The reasons for doing so are non-essential for him. He's in it for the money, at least up until he finds out that Kee has become pregnant. Everything changes with this startling discovery, mainly with those who find out having their own motivations in mind. Kee's child becomes not so much a child, but a symbol for something greater. Wait for the scene where in the middle of an uprising it is discovered theres an infant trapped in the middle of it, everything pauses as the child in slowly taken from harms way in single-shot scene of pure emotion. Corny in explanation, but the film does it right, and with outstanding cinematography everything becomes gritty and the despair is etched onto every scene. This isn't just a grim future that's being painted, it's hell on earth. No one is safe, and nothing looks secure in any sense. That's why we're not all that shocked when Theo is kidnapped, gung-ho style in a scene and whisked away in a van. It looks like an everyday occurrence.

Other notable performances by Julianne Moore round out the film, and of course there's the always excellent Michael Caine playing the secluded hippie Jasper. His role is far more relaxing as you find he takes refuge in a wooded out bungalow, smoking weed and living the lifestyle that seems in stark contrast with the piss poor future that this films portrays. If anything, Children Of Men offers a message of hope, and the idle idea that without children the world becomes an extremely scary place. There's never any exact explanation as to why women have become infertile, and perhaps a bit more would have been nice, but one thing is clear. It isn't so much that there are no more children that makes the world so dark, but what they represent. The scene within the broken down school is eerie and worth noting. Truly a world absent of children is a world in despair.

-Stephen Febick 1/30/12

Gritty and realistic, Alfonso Cuaron's "Children of Men" delivers a dystopian future so masterfully crafted that it is heartbreaking. Everything about this movie is so real that it is terrifying. The year is 2027, but it seems as if the world has regressed into its war-torn past, with the set so well-done that it is wholly convincing. The rest of the movie is built upon such realism. There is no deus ex machina, so much so that at times, the audience is even convinced that the situation is hopeless. In one of the most, if not the most powerful scene of the movie, Theo (Clive Owen) leads Kee (Claire-Hope Ashitey) through scores of fighting people, amidst gunfights and explosions, with the cries of an infant penetrating the din. For a moment, the fighting stops and all eyes turn to the child. For a moment, there is hope. The movie later ends with hope; but it comes shrouded in fog (quite literally). The Human Project mentioned throughout is an enigma that never truly takes form; but it is I believe, part of the intention. Much like Kee's baby, it is symbolic of hope, but it carries with it a measure of uncertainty. But then again, what true hope doesn't?

Yes, it's a compelling dystopian setting, but the screenwriting trips all over itself trying to impress me with how many people die, how many times the hero turns out to be the villain and how many dismembered, disemboweled or deceased corpses can be shown in 2 hours. The movie uses every trick in the book several times over in order to make me feel sad or desperate -- but without compelling, fleshed-out characters or any positive moments of triumph, the depressing parts don't have anything to stand out against. The film as a whole works only to depress me, never letting up, adding layer upon layer of tragedy like the world's saddest birthday cake.

Throw in some questionable directing choices and some of the most heavy-handed symbolism in any movie ever -- seriously, the woman who holds the key to restoring hope to humanity is named "Key" and the boat that will lead them to safety is called "Tomorrow." You've got to be kidding me -- and you have a movie that tries far too hard, and in return gives me very little.

If you have ever seen The Road, or 28 Days Later, you'll recognize the look of Children of Men. It's set in the future in a world that looks familiar, but it's dirtier, grittier and less safe than the world you're used to seeing.

The movie is set in Britain in 2027 and Theo Faron (Owen) learns through a newscast that the world's youngest person has died at the age of 18. Doesn't that sound odd? Have you ever heard a report that sounds anything like that? It immediately alerts us to the fact that something is wrong. We find out that all humans are infertile and no child has been produced for more than 18 years.

If people are no longer born, how long would it take for the world's existing population to die? What would happen to those already here, knowing that they will be among the last of their species?

Theo visits his friend, Jasper (Michael Caine), who hides away in a house in the woods. Illegal immigrants are everywhere and government messages urge people to report them. Theo is abducted early in the story by Julian (Moore) who is his former lover. Movement within the country is restricted and she wants Theo to obtain transfer papers so that her group can take a young woman, Kee, to the coast and safety.

It's a brutal existence and Theo eventually finds himself as Kee's only hope. She's one of the most important people on the planet, but only a small group of people know why. Theo guards her to the best of his ability and attempts to get her to safety using a contact of Jasper's to help them. He accepts help whenever it's offered.

Some of the street scenes would be more at home in a war movie. It seems that the military regularly clashes with civilians and every group has an agenda. It's a crazy existence where law and order is virtually non-existent, and it would be frightening to experience. Do the people have any goals at all that don't involve killing and stealing what they can from others? The military prefers to shoot first and ask questions later.

It impresses me that even though the world is a chaotic place and full of danger, the plot remains coherent. The audience is never in doubt about Theo's intentions; just his ability to succeed. The resolution won't make everyone happy. It's not clear what will happen in the future. This is a snapshot showing one key event in a seemingly hopeless situation. When it's all over, we are left with hope, and that's enough.

No, you fools; you just had to do this sick, twisted, unholy experiment and now humanity is doomed! Seriously guys, you just had to go and try to protect the key to restoring people's ability to have kids. Hey, I don't know about y'all, but this is probably the most appealing dystopian future I've seen yet, where there's no natural disaster thinning out our numbers, and on top of that, there are no more kids bothering us. Yeah, I know that sounds harsh, but if you've got any sense about you, it's not hard to tell that kids, and by extension, society are getting worse, so if we're facing human extinction, we may as well go out while we're... relatively ahead. I'm sure Alfonso Cuarón doesn't want to get rid of kids, because if they weren't around, then he wouldn't have anyone seeing his films, because his most successful stuff have been about kids; and even then, "Prisoner of Azkaban" is the lowest grossing of all of the "Harry Potter" films (Yeah, like that's saying something) and this film didn't make it's budget back. Man, if this film not being terribly successful isn't a definate reflection of how sick our society is becoming, then I don't know what is, because while everyone is going around, enjoying Christmas 2006 with their stupid families and loved ones, this wonderful film about humanity killing itself upon realizing that it's on its last leg is going unseen. Well, as you can tell, I'm a delightful person; and for those who thought that this movie was flawless, then you're going to find me extra delightful, because I stand by my opinion (*cough*fact*cough) that there is no such thing as a flawless film; and sure enough, this film is not above that law.

Right out of the gate, the film is heavily plagued by scientific inaccuracies. Yeah, like I'm suppose to believe that there would be destruction and violence going on because there are no more kids around. No, I know that's not scientifically inaccurate; I just can't get enough of the sounds of a world without kids. I'm sure that there would be plenty of danger and violence going on after universal fertility, which is considered a tragedy... for some reason, because, again, no kids. No, but seriously though, the film is very accurate in its portrayal of this world, but maybe too much so, overemphasizing both the differences and similaries that are found in the day-to-day by showing off a chain of superfluous sequences early on, during the development segment; and when we do transition into scenes of exposition, it's rather forced. As you would imagine, once the story picks up, it abandons those flaws, but brings along slowness that plagues the film heavily and leaves it unable to hold your attention from time to time; and just when you're getting into everything in the final act, Cuarón does it again and pops out a big cop-out ending. Yes, the film's problems are limited, but that's, more often than not, a reflection on the underwhelmingness of a film, more than it is a reflection on the quality; and yet, as you would expect from Alfonso Cuarón, for every bit in the film that stands to be delivered more sharply, there is a solid strength just around the corner that swiftly and effectively enters to pull you back in.

As a visual experience, the film is a real treat, boasting Cuarón's trademark bleakness with a dash of optimism in terms of lighting, as well as slickness and inventiveness in terms of camerawork. There are a good couple of sequences in the film that are all capture in one, single shot; and that is a trick that doesn't feel overbearing, but still remains effective, leaving it to perfectly pull you right into this world for quite the immersive experience. That trick works best during the action sequences, which may be rare, but really knock your socks off, being very well staged and, of course, filmmed well enough to where you feel like you're right there. This creates tension, as well as emotional resonance, because what action there is is still another piece in the storytelling; and with tension in the air - thanks to the immersive cinematography - that storytelling works wonderfully. Of course, it certainly helps that the story is a solid one, as well as believable. As much as I joked about the world being a better place without kids bothering everyone, there's absolutely no way that it would be, because the only thing on everyone's mind is the concept that they are facing the certain "final generation of humanity"; and the world Cuarón presents is so carefully constructed, featuring very human characters with perfectly plausible cause and behavior, thus getting you really invested in this world and what people are left to occupy it. Of course, seeing as I always have to praise performances in a review, I have to say that this film wouldn't be as effective as it is without its wide cast of strong performers, particularly Clive Owen, who's subtle emotion and expressed inner conflict makes him both an effective avatar for the audience and a strong lead character by his own right.

In conclusion, the film is plagued by rather forceful storytelling early-on, but when the story picks up, it ironically "drops" in pace, becoming slow and periodically unengaging, but you keep coming back every time for - if nothing else - the handsome visual style that complements the bittersweet tone of this whole highly believable story, which also finds itself carried by the fine performances that help in making "Children of the Men" the overall fascinating and compelling experience that it is.

3/5 - Good

Mexican director Alfonso Cuarón's (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban) film adaptation of P. D. James' novel (entitled The Children of Men) is a dark, dystopian tale of humanity in the near future. In the year 2035 every single human in the world is infertile. Theo (Clive Owen) is kidnapped by an immigrant rights group known as "The Fishes" whose leader is a former lover of Theo's named Julian Taylor (Julianne Moore) who seeks Theo's help in transporting an illegal immigrant to safety however this illegal immigrant harbours a miracle the world is in desperate need of. Children of Men is a gripping, emotionally engaging and thought provoking film that is helped considerably by one of Clive Owens's best performances, further fine performances of Moore and Michael Caine and Cuarón's exceptional storytelling. Its themes of hope, religion and immigration (some scenes are disturbingly similar to conditions in concentration camps also a fascist British government force feeds propaganda down the public's throats) are presented rather well. Occasionally the script allows the characters to make dramatic speeches in the heat of battle that somewhat takes us out of how realistic the proceedings feel but the innovative single shot action sequences are tense and the viewers willingness for  the success of Theo's mission result in Children of Men being a truly outstanding film.

4.5/5.

A Grown-up sci-fi in a morass of kiddie blockbusters, Cuarón's chilling vision of a dystopian London is gripping and original. Grappling with some heavy issues, while moving with serious speed and intensity, Children of Men bounds from one intricately crafted set piece to another and lets viewers peer into a world in which civilization has been upended because human women have inexplicably lost the ability to have babies. Director Alfonso Cuarón wasn't shy about challenging the boundaries of single-take sequences, as well as loading his adaptation of the P.D. James novel with visual statements on man's cruelty to man and the folly of governing through fear. But he didn't linger on them. Instead, he trusts viewers to absorb the story's subtext and rewarded them with one of the best written dystopian sci-fi films ever. If nothing else, see it for the barnstorming single-take action sequences.

In a bleak vision of a 'post-apocalyptic' (though I hesitate to use that word) world where women have been struck infertile by some unknown cause, Alfonso Cuaron weaves a tragic tale of a man thrust by unusual circumstances into an unusual situation. Rarely have I seen such a vision of the future so beautifully, completely realized. Many times have works that feature otherworldly settings been praised as feeling lived-in, allowing the audience to insert themselves into the setting more completely. This seems literally true with Children of Men. The brilliant cinematography combined with the fantastic art design in all aspects of the work are the true stars here. This is easily one of the best science fiction films in recent times and, indeed, perhaps of all time.

This screen play, written by Timothy J. Sexton and director Alfonso Cuaron (Based off the novel of the same name by P.D. James) draws you into the film and straps you in your chair for  almost a 2 hr. ride without letting up, leaving you wanting, no begging for more. Its so well rounded and worked out and was truly a breath of fresh air within the Sci-Fi Genre. With my griping out of the way, let me touch on the good. The locations were beautifully gritty. All of the abandoned buildings and the refugee camp footage was very well put together. Alfonso Cuaron's "Children Of Men" takes place in the not-too-distant-future where every woman is infertile and world order is on the brink of collapse. Theo Faron (Owen), a conflicted diplomat, is kidnapped by his ex-wife and revolutionary (Moore) to escort a refugee to freedom. However, what Theo doesn't know is that this refugee is in fact a pregnant woman. Thus, a epic and provocative quest ensues.  In this world nearly every country's government has fallen. Therefore, as the only nation left standing, the U.K. must deal with millions of illegal immigrants trying to take refuge within their country. This prompts the U.K. drop into a militarized police state where violence and death are commonplace. Interesting enough, what I enjoyed most about this movie was the atmosphere. The world in "Children Of Men" is so disquieting, and so scary. You can tell that the art directors really took an extensive amount of time to make this setting look as dreary as it's supposed to be. The setting's bleakness is accentuated with really appropriate lighting. However, the cinematography also offers some really beautiful shots of the ravaged U.K. The screenplay is really well written, and it is performed equally as well. Clive Owen really shines in this roles, and Michael Caine plays a character that has a bundle of hilarious lines. Another aspect of this film that I admired is the fact that Cuaron utilized single-shot. This means that when the crap hits the fan for Clive Owen and Co. the cameras never stop rolling and the whole sequence is filmed in one single take. Which brings me to another aspect of "Children Of Men" that I enjoyed - the final sequence of the film. This film's final sequence used the aforementioned action scene technique and it also features a really interesting yet spoilerish dynamic that I can't share. You'll just have to watch it yourself. Overall I felt that "Children Of Men" was an awesome piece of speculative fiction that effectively serves as a cautionary tale for everyone to take seriously.

An incredible, mystical and utterly thought provoking film. I have only just finished watching this film but it has instantly jumped up to number 3 on my top 50 list and I can confidently say without a doubt that this is the best film since Toy Story and easily the best film of the decade. This is the first film of directors Alfonso Cauron which I have seen but his filmmaking technique is incredible, there are very few directors who can make a film that manages to combine so many different genres and sophisticated political and social messages into one 2 hour film.
The premise of children of men does seem to appear to be the usual end of the world crap on the face of it but the threat which the human race faces seems much more real and foreboding than the threat of a Zombie Apocalypse, Nuclear Fallout or a gigantic barrage of meteorites. I have also done some research about infertility rates and read a few articles online and creepily enough I have discovered that infertility rates are rising and it is very creepy to think that the film I just watched is not that far from fiction. 
This film also perfectly captures the desperation and hope which humanity shows in situations of chaos. I can perfectly see the events of this film happening in real life and it makes me worry about the destructive nature of man and just how desperate we could become.
Clive Owen puts on an amazing performance as Theo, a broken man with a big heart, Every action which he performed felt utterly believable and the film didn't depict him as an indestructible action hero who can kill, just as simply as clicking his fingers. He just seems as an ordinary person who has normal morale conflicts just like everybody else. His character is utterly thought provoking because like other characters like 'The Man with No Name', we know very little about his past, and only occasionally do we learn about his past, and I really feel sympathy for him.
All the supporting cast are excellent as well, although Julianne Moore's character is only in the film for around 10 - 20 minutes she plays a vital role in the narrative and provides a good and vital motivation for Theo throughout the film. Michael Caine also shows why he is one of the best actors of all time, his actor provides hints of comedy to the film and perfectly captures that  however desperate humanity gets, there will always be those who try and bring joy to the world, even in dark moments involving him in the film, he still managed to bring a smile to my face. Everyone else throughout the film gives great and believable performances as well.
My favourite part of the film however is the single shot sequences, I have again researched and some of these sequences are around 400 seconds long and they all make the film feels more immersive and involving, very few films manage to do this film without feeling like a documentary or being based on actual events.
 (SPOILER ALERT START))The film also never lingers too much on any certain events, a prime example being when the first baby for around  18 years is born, it is obviously a very important moment for everyone because humanity had basically given up hope for itself or its survival and had just presumed that it would eventually destroy itself. The moment holds much religious connotation and provides many important messages such as hope for humanity and faith in your fellow man. The few minutes of the film which are basically silent, and all that happens that everyone, the freedom fighters,  the fugees and the army all stop and embrace what may be the last shimmer of hope in an otherwise bleak existence. But then the fighting starts again showing that that mankind will always revert back to its usual, violent existence.  (SPOILER ALERT ENDS)
I am not going to give anything away about the ending but there are many possible reactions you could have, you may cry, weep, smile, laugh, pretty much anything. But you must watch the whole film and embrace it for what it is.
Basically, this film cannot be specifically assigned to any one  particular genre, but this is a must see and I really hope that it is as thought provoking and enjoyable as I found it, absolutely breathtaking cinema.

The film deals with the dystopian, near-apocalyptic Britain of 2027. Human females have been infertile for 18 years and the British government has adopted a zero tolerance policy on the hordes of illegal immigrants that are flooding into the country.

That is the horrid sounding vision that this film provides of our future. The entire film forces you to consider the potential perils of pollution, global warming and various acts of man that could bring about this horrific apocalypse. The dangerous, militant Britain that Children of Men portrays really grabs you by the throat and the brutal violence that humanity resorts to lets you into the bare, naked survival-of-the-fittest culture that this society brings.

Visually, the film is perfect. Cuaron's direction portrays the hopelessness of Britain in exactly the right way and the lengthy, single-shot action sequences communicate the brutality of what is essentially an all-out war without the stylised jump cutting of Hollywood action blockbusters.

The film does suffer a little from how it drifts away from its political subtext towards the end and seems to become reminiscent of a Call of Duty game, but the ending provides just the right amount of hope and provides a thought-provoking ending to the kind of film that you'll still be thinking about days later.

When I purchased a DVD copy of this film, I had a high hopes for it; I knew that it was considered as one of best films of the decade.As I began to watch it, it seemed my high hopes were right. But after the first action sequence, the film flat-out lost great potential. The film adopted a simple plot, which was basically going to different places, meeting a person who will help the protagonists, and then repeat until the end. 
Now, there's nothing wrong with a simple plot, but this film had the potential of something much better than that. Character development became no longer necessary when it was "meet n' try to get hell out of here." And to me it was obvious that most of the characters were going to die. The film subtly became predictable.  
Despite that, I don't find this film to be a "bad movie" for three reasons. 1) I found the futuristic setting to be original and realistic unlike other sci-fi future films that force flying cars and what--not. 2) the film has one of the best camerawork I have ever seen, the action sequences were well-made. And 3) Clive Owen's character was very convincing and well-acted; he's was like a modern Winston (reference to the book 1984 for those who don't know). 
It's a shame the plot took a lazy route. I don't see why this film received so much praise It's clearly just a decent film, at least for me. 
I will watch it again some time but I doubt my opinion will drastically change.

I was flicking channels before bed time the other night when I came across this film, it had only just started but I thought I'd watch five minutes... Fifteen minutes later I pressed 'Record' and retired to bed. I'm really glad I recorded it now because, I have to say for the record that I have seen it before but first time around I didn't enjoy it all that much. A second viewing has convinced me that it is a very fine piece of work, gritty, and tough to watch at times, but certainly worth it. More of my thoughts later but here's a brief summary first (summary haters and those that don't wish to know anything about the plot please escort that refugee to the coast while I write the next paragraph).

It is the year 2027 and the world has gone to pot. No babies have been born since 2009 and this has caused chaos across the globe as society collapsed leaving numerous homeless and destitute people. Many make their way to the UK where they are herded into cages and sent to camps far away from the population. When an English man, Theo Faron is approached by his former lover, and leader of a pro-refugee rebellion, Julian, he reluctantly agrees to help her. They need him to escort a girl, Kee, to the coast where they hope to get her on a boat to meet a group of scientists known as 'The Human Project'. Having secured the paperwork from his brother, Theo meets up with Julian, Kee and Miriam (Kee's escort). They set off but are ambushed; they get away and make it to a safe house that proves not to be quite as safe as first thought. Here Theo discovers what is so special about Kee and why it is so important for everyone that she makes it to her destination. I'll leave it there so as not to infuriate the spoiler police... they can get quite nasty you know.

Filmed in a washed-out style, this film is very stark-looking with a realistic feel to it. This really helps the story, which is a no-holds-barred assault on the sensitivities of modern life. It really hits home in a very pragmatic way how society could end up if mankind lets it (ok, no more political stuff). Great performances all round, particularly from Clive Owen as Theo Faron, he seldom convinces me as a leading man, but as the reluctant hero here, he really nails it. Julianne Moore did a good job as Julian (daft name for a girl if you ask me though), as did Pam Ferris as Miriam. I really liked Clare-Hope Ashitey as Kee, she played a difficult part very well, and it was great to see Michael Caine as you've never seen him before, as Theo's friend Jasper.

Amongst all the grit, dirt and general reality of the film comes one scene that will stay with me for a long time. For those that have seen it, it's where Theo and Kee are leaving the tower block and all the fighting stops until they are clear (I don't think I've given anything vital away here). If you haven't seen it, believe me, it's a truly beautiful piece of cinema. There is also a great soundtrack with many songs you'll recognise and a great piece of humour for Pink Floyd fans... just look out of the window at Battersea Power station & you'll see what I mean. Over all, I really enjoyed this film, although I did find it a little too long. There are some great performances and it is a very compelling story... Recommended.

My score: 8.0/10

It's unfair to review Children of Men; how do you review a flawless film? The story is taken from PD James' novel of the same name where women all over the world have become infertile. There are plenty of science fiction films that tell the opposite story of overpopulation so this concept was unique (at least for me). This film doesn't explain why it happens and it doesn't need to because that's not what the film is about. It's about the impending doom that humans have to face only this time it takes its sweet time. 
The characters in the film are hopeless for a change, so when we're shown the full belly of immigrant Kee, the reactions from the main characters breaks that drought of hope and instills determination to take her to safety from chaotic England. 
There isn't much of a original score to the film, but it's better off without one: there are moments where it stays silent, but the tension between characters is felt throughout the room.
I suppose I should keep this review short, so in conclusion, this is the Blade Runner of the 21st Century. This will be the movie that will attract a cult following in the coming years (and it has already started to form).

In the near future, for mysterious reasons not fully explainable, women can no longer concieve children. It's a suttle and weird concept of a story, but Children of Men is far from suttle.

Clive Owen stars as Leo, a man who is stuck between a war ravenged world and a hard place. As he becomes forcably involved with scientist activists fighting for rights for immigrants, who have become treated like the plague in Britain. But there's a conflict: the activists are holding an immigrant woman who is pregnant. This future is a scary one. The world is fighting with eachother, soldiers parade the streets, and if the cities aren't civil enough, outside the city is a constant fight for survival. This is a very interesting concept of a story, and it's great because it views the entire aspect of society and how the situation affects everyone.

Alfonso Cuaron, my hat goes off to you. This film remains thuroughly captivating and breathtaking because of how this movie creates this war stricken world. A competely different look of society is created, and it doesn't even look that impossible. Filmed with almost entirely natural light, there aren't a lot of special gimmics in this movie. This movie looks like you're right into the movie and experience. The camera flows like you're right beside the characters in this very dark enviroment. But what's most impressive are the continuous, one-shot takes. Simplistic in it's way, but extremely hard to do. How the director was able to capture shots like these are mindblowing to me. It's something you have to see for yourself, but an excelent job achieved by the camera man and the actors and crew who were able to achieve these mindblowing shots.

It's not really a political message movie, nor is it a simplistic view of the world. This is an examination of society and how easily the world can fall apart. But is it because no one can give birth, or was the world already like this? Children of Men is an interesting concept done incredably well. One of the best films I have seen this decade. It actually makes you take notice.

The year is 2027, and since 2009 (gulp) the human population of Earth has been unable to repopulate.

This Global infertility has meant that the youngest person on the planet, and symbol of hope "baby" Diego is now 18, and when news comes of his tragic early demise the sense of despair is obvious.

Even prior to this new development civilization was in bad shape, the film is set in London which appears in a constant state of at least semi-anarchy. In fact the opening scene chillingly and brilliantly shows that terrorism and violence is a constant risk. Chaos reigns for much of the city and indeed most major capitals across the world, as refugees from even poorer and more unfortunate locations are constantly rounded up to be shipped to internment camps.

In short it seems that there are clear divisions in the populations, respectable and non-respectable, and you don't want to be in the class with the prefix.

Among all this chaos is Theo, played by Clive Owen, a slightly apathetic everyman seemingly doomed to a life of mediocrity. Theo takes the news of Baby Diego's demise as an excuse to chuck a sickie and visit his hippie-ish friend Jasper, who lives with his catatonic wife in isolation in the middle of nowhere.

Jasper seems to live his life by T-shirt slogans such as "Relax", "Sh*t Happens" and "Don't Worry Be Happy". When all else fails he simply rolls a big joint and takes a temporary exit from existence.

Upon his return to London Theo is almost immediately abducted in broad (muggy English) daylight on the street, upon setting eyes upon his captor he is amazed to see his ex-wife Julian, who has been on the wanted list for some time due to her dodgy activities and associates.

Julian needs help smuggling a refugee out of the country, she hopes that Theo can provide the required papers to facilitate the move. Not wanting to risk his skin Theo initially says no thanks, however once released he approaches his more privileged and connected cousin for the papers, in a scene that reminded me an awful lot of Blade Runner.

Now armed with the documents Theo once again makes contact and says that he will help on one proviso, that he is allowed to tag along.

____________________________________

Theo meets the girl named Kee (wink-wink) and her nanny/minder Miriam and they set off with Julian in tow, and this is where the movie elevates itself above most other movies of the last decade.

It turns out that Kee is pregnant, remember that hasn't happened for some 18 odd years, so Theo is understandably shocked. The film doesn't try to explain how or what it means, only that it is very important.

The very fact that someone was actually able to conceive has been kept top secret, some want to use the information for political means, others more symbolic, and still others want to terminate the "problem".

Julian represents an underground group who wish to deliver Kee to a mysterious organization known as the "Human Project" so that she might be protected and studied, so that an answer might be sought.

Of course everything goes pear shaped when the car they are traveling in is ambushed and Julian is killed, meaning Theo must decide which side he is on and where to go from here.

_________________________________________________

The rest of the film follows Theo and Kee, who has decided he is the only one she trusts, as they attempt to reach a rondezvous with the Human Project.

The filmmakers show no favourites, seemingly important characters are killed off, no-one can be trusted, and violence is unfortunately everywhere, something shown in this film in occasionally graphic detail.

There are some absolutely brilliant set pieces shown in apparently unbroken real time with one camera, these scenes seamlessly blend in long sequences, intricate dialogue and action and stunts, and they are truly awesome.

There is not so much a finale as there is an ending, if that makes sense?, as everything seems to continue building as the film progresses. If there was a finale though, it would happen in a refugee camp, where violence is even more prevalent, chaos reigns and the fact that most of the internees are foreigners results in more confusion for Theo and Kee as they continue onwards.

I don't know much about acting but this all look top notch to me, especially Clive Owen who I have a bit of a man crush on. The film is brilliantly paced and visually striking from beginning to end, and the action is incredibly realistic and therefore has more impact than your standard "bang-bang, you're dead" stuff.

I haven't seen many films that were as original as this, nor have I seen a film that remained with me for as long after the credits rolled.

This is a great film.

Final Rating - 9 / 10. Incredible stuff. Watch it.

There's something odd about a film that you can skip 20 minutes of at a time, and yet still take away exactly the same type of experience. That's where I'm sitting at with Children of Men. I originally watched this film in an English class, skipping through many parts, and only watching about 30 minutes of the actual film. Now that I've gotten the chance to see the entire film, I can't say that there was much point to it.

That's not to say that the film is terrible, in fact, far from it. It just doesn't really require a proper viewing, and if you were to cut out parts of the story that don't really improve the overall story of the film, you would be left with something resembling a 30-40 minute film. A really well-shot, decently acted 30-40 minute film, but that's still what it would be. There isn't much reason to have made Children of Men a full length film, as it just doesn't need that kind of running time to make its impact.

The story takes place in the future. The women of the planet have become infertile, which somehow manages to make the world fall into complete chaos. Britain is the only place left on Earth that managed to stay as a decent place to live, and as such, immigration has become a problem. The film revolves around Theo Faron (Clive Owen), who gets convinced to help women (Claire-Hope Ashitey) find safe transit out of London. It turns out that this women is pregnant, the first pregnant women in 18 years. A group of people want to use this child as a signal of hope to rally the people. Here lies the main problem the film has.

The story doesn't require long to tell at all. There are many events that occur that don't end up meaning anything by the end, with some characters coming and going without much purpose. It was especially disappointing to see Michael Caine's character show up, disappear for a large amount of time, then reappear only to disappear again quickly after. It's especially sad when his character is not only one of the more important supporting characters, one of an aging hippie, but also the most interesting character in the film.

There is also a problem with the premise itself. The still-unborn child is supposed to represent hope. Things can improve, preaches the film. That doesn't make any sense. One pregnant woman doesn't symbolize hope for the entire planet! All it does is say that there might be a slight chance that the unexplained infertility crisis may be over. The rest of the planet is still in ruins. We are shown this near the beginning. Nowhere else is really even livable anymore. Even if this birth-to-be means that the human race is coming out of this problem, there are still far too many other ones we would have to deal with. Riots, overpopulation, resource depletion, and not to mention the inevitable global warming that comes from many of these things.

What's most surprising about this film is the fact that the superfluous parts that could easily be cut out manage to still be interesting. They're unnecessary, sure, but that doesn't necessarily render them useless. There are times in which the story can really draw you in, and while it these plot points make no impact on the final result of the film, they manage to entertain, if nothing else.

The best thing that Children of Men has going for it is its cinematography. Unlike many science fiction films, the special effects don't carry it. This is refreshing, and allows the viewer to focus on the scenery and the way things are shot, rather than things like CGI monsters. There are many single-shot sequences used in the film, ones that really manage to stand out. They're quite beautiful to look at, and while I'm sure they were tough to film, they end up being the highlights of the film.

The other thing the film has going for it is its acting. While the lead performance of Clive Owen didn't resonate with me well, the supporting cast managed to make up for it. Michael Caine and Clare-Hope Ashitey were especially good in their roles, and they made us care for them and their situations. Clive Owen, however, felt hollow as the lead, and while this may be intentional given that his character didn't appear to care much for the world, it was off-putting.

Children of Men felt like a short film that had to fill up an hour and a half running time. It had many plot points that didn't go anywhere, and while these parts are interesting, connecting them to the rest of the story certainly would have been appreciated. The premise seemed quite silly to me, not really making a lot of sense. The acting was overall decent, and the film was shot beautifully. WARNING _ SPOILER ALERT!

At first when I saw the title Children Of Men, I thought it was just a typical horror flick. But then when I heard how good it was ( It was 2nd ranked by Peter Travers of Rolling Stone as one of the best movies of the last decade) I thought 'Yeah I should give it a try. Let's see how it is'.

Children Of Men takes place in 2027 and it has been 18 years since the last child was born. Now he then got killed and London bureaucrat Theo (Clive Owen) seems to cared since he used to be an activist for an unknown cause. Now, England is being controlled by British police and the government turns totalitarian with its policies on illegal immigrants. The immigrants also known as Fugees come in great numbers to England. Not only that, all of the world women's are infertile so there were no kids born between 2009 and the year the film is set.

Theo is asked by his ex-girlfriend Julian (Julianne Moore), the leader of The Fishes, an anti government organisation with a set of beliefs on human rights, to help an African refugee Kee to escape from England to the Human Project so she can be able to look after her unborn baby. Julian is killed afterwards and when Theo discovers that the Fishes' were responsible for Julian's death, he decided to bring Kee along with Fishes member Miriam themselves to a boat.

Children Of Men looks similar, in a way, to District 9 released last year. They're both set in the future and it's kinda has the same concept. Both have issues with immigration and racism. Even though District 9 focused on aliens, Children Of Men focused on humans and it is anything apart from science fiction.

The movie's cinematography and direction from Alfonso Cuaron (he directed Harry Potter and The Prisoner of Azkerban) is so gritty with an idealistic screenplay from Timothy J Sexton.

Clive Owen brings in subtlety towards his character. You would want to care for him as well as the pregnant Kee. Julianne Moore puts in a nice performance as well as Michael Caine who suprisingly plays a hippie with his posh accent.

Interestingly, Cuaron has the camera around in one take making it one scene held for a long time while things are still happening. This takes the film into and around the edge even when the film is put as an experiment. But unless you can handle it while watching, you're more likely to get sick because many scenes are shot hand held.

Cuaron takes the plot into more ideas as we predict of facing a crisis on illegal immigrants and infertility. One thing is that when Kee gave birth, the baby is a symbolism of hope during one scene where the Fishes and the British military are in conflict. This also takes up rebellion, as the Fishes show how violent activists are when are taking on the government over issues affecting them.

When Australia is facing a problem with our overpopulation, and just recently a Chinese dissentant who is a human rights activist is awarded the Nobel Peace Price, Children Of Men's main focus is human rights. Whenever you look in the background you see guards treating migrants as dirt and mostly putting them to death and it promotes this awareness through the mass media as you'll see slogans such as 'Report Illegal Immigrants' everywhere.

So is Children Of Men is as perfect as it should be? Quite not. I think it would have been better if Julianne Moore (I have to admit, I never seen her in film before) and Michael Caine had more screen time instead of just dying. That would have been character development had their characters never been killed. And it would have made sense of the plot has a background of how the world problems occured.

Children of Men is a futuristic movie with a difference. It is all about to keep the survival of a person holding the key of the endangered human race. To say that a science fiction needs ideas to keep us entertained can be an exagerration, but Children Of Men is one of those movies in the genres that has many ideas that will keep us in grips.

An excellent movie set in Britain during 2027 where the world is in the grip of an infertility crisis. Societies worldwide have collapsed after no children have been born in almost two decades, and the survivors of the ensuing wars, atrocities and civil breakdowns flee to Britain, which still functions under a harsh regime. The last young person has just died. Theo, a former activist now working as a paper-pusher in the Ministry of Energy must help and protect a pregnant woman to get to the East coast in order to get onboard a ship which will take care of her and her baby. 

I loved this movie. I wasn't quite expecting it to be so good and went into it knowing extremely little about it which is probably how it actually should be viewed. There aren't any flaws at all. The acting is brilliant -Clive Owen gives what I think is his best performance and Julianne Moore, Michael Caine, Chiwetal Ejiofor, and Pam Ferris are all superb in support, while the young Claire-Hope Ashitay is also impressive as Kee. The movie is of a genre done before, yet feels fresh, from the scripting to the look of the movie. There are some genuine shocks in store. Thanks to Alfonso Cuaran's fantastic camera-work, the violence becomes more brutal, the acting more powerful and the shocks are so realistic that you frequently feel as though you're watching real footage. Scenes such as the drive through the forest look so real that they are excruciatingly tense and absolutely terrifying to watch. Children Of Men is surely a landmark in cinema, and will certainly gain in reputation as the years go by.

An amazing film! Not only is it beautifully scripted, acted, and shot, but it is also thought-provoking. (I just have to emphasize the cinematography in this film-it truly sucks you into this dystopian sci-fi world)

Several ground-breaking, amazing real-time one-take sequences take place during this powerfully dark and gloomy story.  Clive Owen is one of the least likely heroes, dragged along kicking and screaming until he finds the will to help mankind.

Some movies are so depressing that they're strangely exhilarating. Children of Men, however, is the real deal, a proper, no-nonsense, 109-minute downer-fest of impossible bleakness. It's set in 2027 London, 25 years after the Last Baby Ever was born--and the fact that humanity is seemingly doomed to go extinct through mere sterility has brought about all kinds of nasty shit. There is a (very) faint glimmer of hope for the world at the end, and Michael Caine's ageing hippy character provides some humour, but overall I think that The Darkness prevails. Clive Owen's permanently sullen expression does little to help, as the fact that the movie takes itself a tad too seriously.

On the other hand, Children of Men is formally brilliant. For one thing, it's really cool how the whole "future" element is subtly downplayed. Most importantly, however, there are at least three lengthy and wonderfully complex single-shot sequences, the mere thought of which fills me with admiration and longing to see the movie again.

I know it seems I give 100% ratings to a lot of movies, but this film (and I can truly call it a "Film" in good confidence) truly deserves it. Children of Men happens to be one of the best and most thought-provoking (I know, that term gets thrown around a lot) sci-fi movies I've ever seen.

The year is 2027, and it has been eighteen years since the last child was born. The world has been thrown into chaos by this plague of infertility and every country, save Britain, has collapsed, and Britain isn't far off. Theo, played by Clive Owen, is contacted by his rebel wife to escort a refugee out of the country. Things get complicated and after a violent and narrow escape, Theo discovers that this isn't any normal "fugee":  she's pregnant. His struggle then becomes to keep her away from both the government and the rebel cell, who wishes to use the baby to spur a rebellion.

I just don't even know where to begin with Children of Men. How about the performances? The entire cast is spectacular. Clive Owen has his best role yet in a movie and he plays this character just right. Julianne Moore is superb, and my only complaint is that she isn't in the movie long enough. Michael Caine absolutely steals every scene he's in, giving possibly the only comic relief in this entire movie. If you want a reason why he's one of my favorite actors, watch this movie.

The story is excellent as well. I've never wondered what would happen if people just stopped giving birth, but the effects are beautifully realized here. The film has an overall depressing and gloomy tone, but the ending was so beautiful and positive (I think I may have cried when at the beginning of the credits, and I think you'll know what I'm talking about when you see it). Several scenes are just beautiful, particularly a one in a building where a battle is raging, and the sound of this baby crying causes every soldier and civilian to stop and gaze in awe. There's no music or dialogue, just the sound of the baby crying and the peoples' reactions. It's captivating.

Camerawork doesn't usually get mention in my reviews, but it's well worth noting here. It's simply impressive. It's shot in a shaky-cam style (more Bourne than Blair Witch), but never impedes the view of the action as in the previously mentioned films. Also there are numerous tracking shots that span about five to ten minutes with no edits or anything, and you don't even realize it until it's over. One particular scene takes place completely from the perspective of inside the car as the passengers go from trading stories and jokes to being scared for their lives as the vehicle is attacked.

Children of Men is a brilliantly realized film. Just every part of the film is amazing and it deserves attention. It's definitely has one of the most satisfying endings I've ever seen in a movie. It goes down in my book as one of the best examples of "thinking-man's" sci-fi without overdoing it, and one of my favorites.

With so many potentially cataclysmic irons in the fire these days (Global Warming, flu pandemic, Rosie ODonnells return to television), post-apocalyptic thrillers may seem, for the first time in film history, a bit too timely. The good (Escape from New York), the bad (The Postman), and the ugly (Freejack) of this sub-genre only hinted at the possible future that Children of Men cunningly gives immediacy tobut only as window-dressing. Smartly, the movie exists not to pontificate on contemporary affairs, but to tell a well-woven tale of hope and survival in face of calamity.

In this R-rated sci-fi drama about a futuristic society where mankind has lost the ability to reproduce, a former activist (Owen) is drafted by a resistance leader (Moore) to shepherd a pregnant woman through England, which has been placed under martial law. 

Alfonso Cuaron, director of Y Tu Mama Tambien and Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, is the rare director who can make audiences see the forest through the trees. With long, continuous, unedited shots, Cuaron makes moviegoers fellow journeymen on this war-torn sojourn, building on the emotion and tension of being a character in-the-moment over an extended period of time. The audience feels the debris from a blown-apart building. The audience jumps in their seats when refugees throw bottles. The audience feels the war-torn world fall into a hush when a babys cry is heard. It proves to be a feat few artists can successfully pull off, capturing a light in the fog that even the most discerning eye can perfectly see.    

Bottom line: This bleak future looks bright.

Instead of a macho gun-toting action star, Clive's character is wholly unprepared for the trials he faces and the enormous job of protecting humanity's last hope. And in his flaws and reluctance and weakness is his believability. The mother's character was also very well done as the archetypal Madonna presented in an entirely unusual and unexpected way. This woman was perfect and yet completely unprepared for the role of 'mother of the future'. Together, they carried the film very well, and it is their characters that I will remember the most.

Two things I didn't like: 

Parts of it were downright boring. Parts of it didn't make much sense within the context of the larger film (mostly at the beginning), and parts of it just seemed superfluous or there merely for shock value. There was too much going on outside of the core plot that it seemed to take away from the main quest to get the mother and baby to safety. 

The political commentary about the treatment of outsiders and immigrants was compelling, but could have played a slightly lesser role. As it was, I felt that this sub-story completely overwhelmed the main plot and only led to confusion and frustration. It was as if the writers were trying to squeeze ten hours worth of story into a two hour film. My other problem was the ending. I didn't like it. It was downright anticlimactic, and it didn't provide any sense of closure at all. After all that had happened, I expected more. 

A good story, a fantastic and downright frightening premise, but as a movie could have been better executed.

Perhaps the only film I can think of where the premise is pretty silly but the execution is brilliant. This is an unexpected masterpiece that few people seem to know about yet I expect will become highly regarded and popular on video given a few more years. It's a classic by my standards and I frequently find myself referencing this film as the standard for a great modern film.

Allow me to recreate my experience of this film and perhaps you'll understand why I'm so drawn to it. Generally, when I get ready to watch a film I entirely expect to hate, I set up my computer and get some work done as I watch it. This film started off the same: a futuristic world where women can no longer bear children for some unexplained reason--science so soft it makes Star Trek look like the Mythbusters. Whatever, get my laptop and start wikipedia-ing the first random noun that pops into my head. Oh, I didn't know Han Solo was originally concieved as a giant 7-foot lizard, that totally would have ruined the movie and made me--HOLY CRAP DID THAT COFFEE SHOP JUST 'SPLODE!!!

I got hooked. I put my laptop away and watched this movie from beginning to end without ever getting bored or looking for something else to do. That's part of the appeal of this film, its ability to surprise. This isn't just one isolated event, the movie is filled with countless eye-popping, realistic moments that draw you into the story and the characters. Nothing comes off as far-fetched, in fact even the futuristic feel of the movie is toned down to the point where you can see this world being plausible in ten or twenty years (as oppossed to the traditional flying cars and colonies on the moon schtick). Like farting in a crowded elevator, this movie envelops you with its atmosphere.

Another typical Hollywood moment this movie consciously sidesteps is the necessity of a love interest for the protagonist. I groaned when Julianne Moore stepped on-screen as Clive Owen's ex-wife and hinted at a future hook-up. Fortunately the movie saw this looming disaster of predictability and (SPOILER ALERT) promptly shot her in the head during a spectacular car chase. "Alright," the movie seemed to say, slapping its hands together to remove the dirt from her freshly dug grave, "back to the good stuff." 

The car chase also demonstrates another strong aspect of the film--the art of the single-shot. Unlike a Michael Bay film (can you tell I don't like him yet?) who spits out shots like Woody Allen does movies, Alfonso Cuaron pushes the limit of what he can get into a single scene. Actually, until this movie I never realized how short most shots are in other films. I suppose they do this becuase they believe short shots keep the action flowing but Cuaron proves just how wrong they are with the final battle scene--an epic five minutes of Owen darting between cover as all hell erupts around him. What Cuaron does best is immersion, he makes you feel as if you're in this reality.

This is a great film, the best I've seen in years. The action is gripping, the characters are flawed but likeable, the atmosphere is perfect, the messages are subtle and well-thought out, and the story is...well, there--its not amazing yet it holds everything together pretty well. I consider it more about a dystopian future and the people who inhabit it rather than a story you'll tell your kids at bedtime. For a crazy premise about global infertility, it portrays the world richly enough that I believe if such an infeasible tragedy occured it would look like this. Maybe you'll disagree with that but I can promise you one thing: you'll love every minute of it. Now go enjoy the blessing of fertility, make 'dem babies.

An almost futuristic dsytopian society, yet realistic and seemingly true, Children of Men is an engaging and fraught with tension thriller that pushes the boundaries of acceptable worlds. Though many films misuse the term futuristic to include out of this world inventions, cataclysmic empires that reach vast lengths, ruled by some evildoer, and an inconceivable universe Children of Men takes place only a bit down the line, knows when to keep cool under pressure, and advances its plot based on the characters and not a contentious ideal of what the future will be like in twenty years. Some amazing acting from a cast that reaches down deep, including an activist Julianne Moore, scientist Michael Caine, and our lead Clive Owen, a man who has given up hope though in his youth he was just the same wild idealist as his former partner. The film moves at a fast pace, and explains itself as it goes. The main idea seems to be that human life, however eroded by greed and corruption, is worth preserving, and even in a world that seems to have ordered chaos, there is always a hand climbing out of the darkness to capture you. I thought the performances were the best part, especially that of Michael Caine who plays a role so unlike him, and yet works well with his own talents. Owen is usually the brash action star or the quiet man behind the scenes, but here he downplays his entire involvement, conceding that the mother of the first child in the world is obviously the hero of the story, and leads her to Earth's victory, however bittersweet. I loved the cinematography, the one shot action scenes of explosions and subterfuge, and the story itself, which stands as one unobstructed by petty villains, insidious government actions, and high brow heroes with inferiority complexes. Though cultural and political differences are shown in an almost heavyhanded approach, I liked it still, because it was somewhat honest and looked to the future with a broad understanding of socio-economic ties, as well as the intentions of the media and the roles of poor individuals and their motives and ensuing actions. Really a stark realization of what lies ahead.

Alfonso Cuaron's direction is hit and miss for me.  I think his vision is dark and distinctive, but it doesn't work in some of the franchises he's been hired to work in.  Case in point: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.  The world he created is unique to him, yes, but doesn't work as a translation of the novel. 

Children of Men is nothing short of a masterpiece thanks to Cuaron's directing though.  It's a beautiful, elegaic film that starts at the end of civilization.  Humans have lost the ability to reproduce, and the youngest man on earth, the last baby ever born, is killed in a terrorist attack.  Clive Owen's character Theo watches this happen with all the apathy and world-weariness of a man who's lived too long in a world too bleak.  He seems a poor recruit for Julianne Moore's character, who asks him to help her protect the world's most precious cargo: a pregnant young woman.  

There are times when Children of Men feels oppressively dark.  The world Cuaron creates is so vivid, so real, and so believable that it drinks in its audience and demands attention.  It's a visceral film, one that crawls under your skin and lingers long after the credits roll.  But Children of Men is also a film about hope, and somehow, amidst all the death and destruction, this fact is never forgotten and always exists on the periphery of the audience and the characters' vision.
