I believe this to be one of the greatest movies ever made, regardless of genre. No art is created in a vacuum. I say this because so often when some people read about a work being compared to a prior film they assume the new film lacks originality. Well, Children of Men is brimming with originality, yet I find myself reminded of other great motion pictures. Perhaps surprisingly I think of Fellini's Satyricon which depicts an ancient era that eerily feels futuristic, with the protagonist stumbling across grotesques throughout. Children mirrors this in that it's future looks starkly like the collapsing of any historical empire, characters trying to sort out some personal salvation - by  mysticism, political revolution, etc. 

I find a palatable sense that this is a conscious anti-Blade Runner, in it's sly unobtrusive technology scattered throughout vs. Ridley Scott's in-your-face Sci-Fi Futurism. Still, in an odd way they make possible companions for a double feature. As if in parallel universes both main characters are dragged out of a life of Kafkaesque resignation into a mission to deal with outcasts trying to blend into society. Both eventually become immersed in their respective missions and appear capable of giving the supreme sacrifice at the end of their films, despite initially harboring no strong convictions about anything. Like Blade Runner, I think Children of Men will grow in esteem and people will eventually look back and wonder why the film wasn't a much bigger success.

Children Of Men.

Whenever I hear those three words, whether in context or not, I immediately go into fanboy mode and start geeking out and professing my everlasting love for this masterpiece of cinema.

In my opinion, one of the most criminally underrated films of all time. This bleak, invigorating and thought-provoking look into "what could be" the future is pure cinematic gold.

Whether it be the absolutely astonishing Cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki, the masterful direction by Alfonso Cuaron or the great performances by the cast, this film is mesmerizing.

Set in a dystopian United Kingdom in 2027 where no child has been born in the entire world for 25 years and most of the world is in ruins. But "Britain Soldiers On!" in the film. A fascist, monarchic country is what Britain has become.

I don't really want to go into full on plot synopsis because I could type for hours about this film and if you don't know the plot of the film, GO LOOK IT UP, NOW.

As I was saying. Children Of Men is a film that literally works on all levels. It's an intelligent and thought-provoking drama, a exciting and incredibly well-done action movie and a bleak look into the future.

The film is bolstered by top-notch performances by the Cast, with many notable performances from Clive Owen, Julianne Moore and especially Michael Caine who, quite frankly, surprised me with his very offbeat and eccentric performance as the cannabis-smoking political activist and former political cartoonist, "Jasper".

The cinematography is revolutionary in this film. One of director Alfonso Cuaron's cinematic trademarks, long "one-take" shots that usually involve many complex actions taking place in the background and foreground is in full play in this movie. I cannot explain this film's cinematography with words, an since that's all I'm able to do on Rotten Tomatoes, I can merely encourage everyone to view this film for all its worth.

This film deserved more commercial recognition and recognition from the Academy and various other Film Award Ceremonies.

Give this film it's due and go buy it and enjoy it today.

The year is 2027, there hasn't been a child born in 18 years. The world is in tatters and only London stands tall. But the cost was great; London is now a landfill of death, violence and injustice. We follow Theo (Clive Owen) on a journey that could, maybe, just maybe, give back the world the hope it so desperate needs. 
 
Children Of Men starts with an explosion, a shock that doesn't let up for a single second for all it's 109 minuets runtime. To give such a bold and bleak interpretation of the world can only come from the mind of the man that took the fluffy franchise which was Harry Potter, turned it on it's head and into the brilliance which was The Prisoner Of Azkaban,  I speak of course of Alfonso Cuarón. 

Cuarón  depressing glance into the future will shake each of us to our very souls, that is one of the more unique things about Children Of Men, that unlike other films set in the future, (eg: I, Robot orMinority Report,) the future Cuarón depicts is believable. Personally, I attribute this realism to the fact that the future Cuarón sees is deep rotted in the present we live in today. Children Of Men has no flying cars, that run of LSD or thoughts of heroes, their cars are the same as today's only more aware of danger with installed windows to give advanced warning to the drivers; it's the subtle things like that which make Children Of Men special. Another example is that Dope is still illegal. The smallest details are thought of in Children Of Men, and it all adds in it's favor.

If you can imagine and cope with it, Children Of Men is bleaker than V for Vendetta. The film is set in a baron and disfigured London town, where terrorism is everywhere, and no one is safe. This makes us feel as an audience... edgy, like anything could happen. Children Of Men has no guarantees, only the power of the film itself. 

1984 for this generation. Children Of Men is shocking, compelling and intimidating and amazing. Everyone without exception should see this film.

Children of Men is a science fiction thriller of sorts. It seems to hang its hat on action sequences rather than storytelling, and this is the primary reason I did not enjoy the film as much as the community at large. However, in the areas where the film succeeds, it succeeds quite marvelously. Ultimately, I felt like the film's story left a few important questions left unanswered. 

The film has an engaging premise. The year is 2027. Women have become infertile (or it could be that men are shooting blanks - it is never really explained). No child has been born in 18 years. It seems that the current 18-year-old generation is the last generation of humanity. What is to be done? How can humanity be saved, if it can be saved at all? The film takes off from there, moving at what I considered to be an enjoyably aggressive pace. 

The film takes place in Britain, and since it is only 18 years in the future, the city-scapes are very familiar, resembling what we are used to. However, the buildings, the streets, and the people are in a sickening state of decay. The sets impressively render these ominous details, and this decomposing environment help to infect the film's hectic plot with an added degree of bleakness. 

Clive Owen stars in this film, playing a man named Theo. Initially, Theo seems detached from the world's sad state, indifferent to what appears to be the impending apocalypse. After twenty years of separation, he is unexpectedly contacted by his ex-wife, who has become heavily involved in an anti-government faction. This faction is bent on inciting what they call "The Uprising," which is basically an overthrow of the current government. Theo's ex-wife needs his help. Reluctantly, Theo agrees to help her. I had problems here. At first, Theo's indifference seemed unshakable. Then he becomes wrapped up in this anti-government movement. This transformation is fine and interesting, I just thought the conviction with which Clive Owen embodied the transformation was a bit unconvincing. To me, it felt feigned. 

The film's story is at once intriguing, but to me, it quickly became saturated in simplicity, leaving important holes in the plot unexplained. For example, humans have become unable to reproduce. How did this happen? Why did it happen? These questions are not addressed. In the film 28 Days Later, we are offered that first introductory scene with the chimps who have been infected with rage. Though brief, it provides an explanation of how the world came to be in the sad state it is in when the film takes place. In Children of Men, we are offered no such explanation. This bothered me. 

Without spoiling the film's plot, my next issue is geared towards those who have seen the film. It pertains to the young girl whom Theo strives to protect. Her name is Kee. My question is: Why her? Why is she so special? What is it about her that allows her to perform what is perceived as a miracle? In the context of the film's story, it occurs to me that her extraordinary condition is worthy of explanation. Perhaps it is unfair of me, but I demanded an explanation, and I never received one. 

Lastly, because of the story's simplicity, I felt like the film descended into action sequences. There's nothing wrong with this. In fact, some of the action sequences were brilliant and shot with incredible innovation. However, I felt like the extensive action in the film was a substitute for what could've been an extremely interesting and engaging story. 

Children of Men is a good film. Don't get me wrong. I liked it. It has been well-received by the vast majority of film fans. And I feel I understand why. It is engaging and demands your attention. The movement of the film is riveting. I just didn't feel the film realized its potential in terms of story. And I will admit, my main focus of film is on the story. So perhaps I am criticizing the film from the wrong angle. 

Anyway, I would recommend the film to anyone. It is spontaneous and engrossing. Surely, it is entertaining. I don't think anyone would regret having seen this film.

What can I say, I'm just a sunny kinda guy:  continuing with my recent tour of films about the apocalypse, I turn now to Alfonso Cuaron's "Children of Men."  The first thing that I have to report is that this film is just as grim as, but far more engaging than, my last experience with Michael Haneke's awful "Time of the Wolf."  Perhaps the difference is that the characters here are not deflated, listless, and beaten; they are actively resisting their fates.  Perhaps the difference is in production values; which is to say, "Children of Men" has some.  And they are fairly awesome.  This is a fully fleshed-out world; in Haneke's film I felt detached from the protaganists despite the gritty realism, but here the burnt-out buildings, rubble-strewn streets, and omnidirectional gunfire are irresistably all-encompassing.  I felt the urge to duck in my seat at several points.  Clive Owen nails the feel of his role exactly; he is not an indestructible action hero, just an ordinary guy completely freaked by the mess he's gotten himself into.  He is Theo, a low-level government employee in a Britain which stands as the world's last-remaining organized nation.  Catastrophe and violence have erupted across the globe with the realization that the human race, for reasons unknown, has become sterile (I have a problem with this premise, but more on that later).  He has a whacked out, aged-hippie friend (Michael Caine) with a hidden place in the woods where they both get high.  The country is exploding in violence all around him as it forcibly removes illegal immigrants.  There is a resistance movement, headed by Theo's ex-lover (Julianne Moore, terrific as always).  They had a child together, a child that died.  He has not seen her in a long, long time.  She wants something from him:  she asks him to use his position to fabricate transit papers for a mysterious young immigrant woman named Kee (Clare-Hope Ashitey).  He wants something from her:  he needs money.  They are obviously still in love.  Kee is preganant.  Moore's group, the Fishes, fears that if the pregnancy became public Kee and her baby would be interned and exploited by the British government.  When Theo obtains the transit papers, they specify that he must accompany her to the coast.  Not all of the Fishes are what they appear to be.  Soon, Theo will find himself surrounded by horror and loss.  He will become an honorary mid-wife as he and Kee run from...well, everybody.  The actors all convey their respective desperations so realistically that I was tempted to take my pulse, or a valium.  This movie is intense.  The scenes of action are not slick kinetic ballet, but rather frantic scrabbles for survival, executed with hair's-breath timing and genuine suspense.  There is much we don't learn about the sterility, the world-wide collapse, and the reason for Kee's pregnancy, and this is intentional.  We are trapped in the London fog with these people, and we feel with them and for them.  The execution of this film is virtually flawless, and I was genuinely swept up in the drama.  A word about this premise though:  The movie is based on a novel by P.D. James.  I've been watching these end of the world flicks in a comp lit class that I am taking, and the professor mentioned that in the novel, the world hasn't gone to the hell in a handbasket that it appears as in the cinematic version.  I assume that this decision was made in order to lend gravity to the drama, but it distracted me with questions like:  wouldn't a decrease in the human population, short-term, lead to BETTER living conditions?  Ya know, less competition for resources, that kind of thing?  Isn't it possible that UNIVERSAL human sterility might bring mankind together in the search for a cure?  Obviously, the inability to produce children becomes a rather thorny catastrophe for society a few decades down the road, but I don't understand why it would produce war.  What are these nations and people fighting over, exactly?  Put the politics aside though, and what you have is a thoroughly powerful human drama about maintaining one's humanity in a world where civilization has broken down.  Theo begins the movie searching for weed, booze, and a place where he doesn't have to watch the news.  He will soon put out the blunt and poor out the bottle; he takes one look at preganant Kee and discovers that he's not as apathetic as he thought.  As the "Children of Men" fight over The Fate Of The World, one woman holds the key to its survival.  She will remind Theo, and us, that we have the power to change, to make new and life-affirming choices, right up until the hour of our deaths.

Children of Men is a brilliant post apocalyptic drama. It's undoubtedly Alfonso Cuaron's best film to date. That's right, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (my favorite installment in the series) is only number two. This film portrays a scary world where new children have not been born in eighteen years due to a pandemic flu that has made its way across the entire globe. Because of that, humanity is on the verge of extinction after the remaining life has died off. All of the countries have collapsed, except for the United Kingdom's, who is now the only livable place left. The British government is doing all it can to keep the endless flocks of immigrants who seek refuge out, meanwhile an anti government group called Fishes is plotting an up rise to fight for the immigrants who do not get treated equally. 

It's a very heavy plot to grasp. Not complicated, but the tone of this film is so somber, and it never lets up. I was almost depressed watching it, but the last twenty minutes or so really helped to get the weight off of my shoulders. For such a dark toned film, it has a beautifully bright appearance (some of the cinematography I've ever seen). I really don't know how else to explain it, but its beautiful. The scariest part to me is that it was set only seventeen years from now (2027, for those of you who cannot add...:P). This is, without a doubt, one of the best post apocalyptic movies ever made. It may be too soon to call it a classic, but I'll do it anyway. The cast is top notch. Clive Owen, Michael Caine, Julianne Moore and Chiwetel Ejiofor are the only recognizable actors in it, but everyone with the slightest bit of screen time was phenomenal. This is a damn near perfect film. How it didn't go home with a single Academy Award is far beyond me. I highly recommend Children of Men to everyone.

One of my favourites and one of the very best movies I have seen in my short lifetime. It is simply unbelievable how deep the message of this movie reaches and how much there is to find underneath the surface, the surface that is cruel, dirty and relentless. It really takes a great deal of commitment for something like this, a mish mash of emotions, action and art to appear as a picture acceptable for wider crowds. This movie balances unbelievably well between art and entertainment and it probably did deserve more than just three nominations, but I have long ago stopped narrowing myself with the statuettes to determine the film's virtue instead of me. There are so much allusions of today's society that it is hard to even notice all of them. The whole genre of Science Fiction actually has a purpose of showing the todays society as a one big allegory, with an exception of those SciFi movies that only try to entertain you (in a very shallow way most of the time), and Children of Men succeded in both.

So, the story of this one is set in 2027. and the refugees from all over the world are swarming into Britain where the authorities brutally capture and cram them into refugee camps. The conditions there are probably almost as bad as in the countries they have fled from. I didn't mention that the whole civilization is facing extinction as the women are infertile and the youngest person was born back in the year of 2009. The main character is Theo played by Clive Owen and although he has enough worries of his own, he is about to become a guardian of a refugee girl carying an unborn child, a so called miracle. She becomes the target of the government and the extremist groups also and Theo must do everything to protect the girl and the baby too.

Now, I'd like to say something about the camerawork in this movie. I have never noticed a so conspicuos lenght of a one cut. It really worked for me as something innovative, and was particulary effective in some action scenes, like the siege at Bexhill which is maybe my favourite scene from a movie I have ever seen. It functioned so real and live that some of the action directors could use this scene as a model for their projects. Really stunning stuff, although at the end of this long cut comes the only part of the movie I did not like. That small part tends to be a cliche and it is a bit hard to believe it would happen, but with this small minus I still think the film is near perfection.

Clive Owen won me over with this role. I have seen him in several movies but I think this is his absolute number one. I have a very high opinion of his movie and role choosing and alongside Children of Men I thought he was excellent in Sin City, Closer, King Arthur and The Bourne Identity. There are much more movies I haven't seen him in and I'd very much like to. His character of Theo Faron seems very simple and everyday-like at first but step by step we are introduced with his inner fights and painful past which I thought Owen developed very well throughout the story.
Michael Caine is someone i just like to see. His appearance is something special and wherever I have seen him I've really liked him. During the movie I heard the mumbling of my native language among the refugees and extremists of Britain which really made me laugh at times. It is actually quite interesting how many parallels this story has with the Bible, particulary the part where a girl is carrying a baby that is supposed to be the hope and salvation for mankind. Some additional data I've read also got me thinking like the fact that Theo never used a firearm during the whole movie, or that he never got a chance to smoke a cigarette 'till the end. The name Theo Faron means «The God Of Lighthouses» in Greek which could be interpret in various ways. I was stunned by the large painting of Guernica on the wall, which has obvious meaning in real life and in Children of Men it only adds up to the artistic feeling.

Anyone who cares one bit about the quality of the movie, about something that surpasses entertainment only, should feel obliged to see this. I will never forget Children of Men and I'll be glad to see it a few more times. Recommendations to absolutely everyone.

Children of Men is one of the finest Dystopian films I have seen in many years. The film opens on a dirty London street with the news on a TV in a coffee shop. It's obvious that most of the world is blown to shit and Britain is one of the last bastions of civilization in the world. We then see news of the youngest man in the world being killed. Now, the idea of everyone knowing who the youngest person in the world is, is, for me striking. The idea that in a hundred years there will be no people left. What the hell. The reason why women have been left infertile is not known, at least, it's not public if it is known. Clive Owen plays a government employee by the name of Theo Farron, who's ex wife just happens to be the leader of a civil rights organization that is trying to get the British government to stop their persecution of illegal immigrants. Theo is contacted after many years by his ex wife and is asked to secure safe passage out of Britain to the Azores for a young female named Kee. It is later shown that Kee is pregnant. Let that sink in, the first pregancy in 18 years. That's quite a thought, and not really in a hopeful way. This kid hasn't a chance, in my mind, not even if Kee makes it to "The Human Project" which is some sort of scientist commune in the Azores committed to curing infertility. The atmosphere in the film is dark, gritty and just a tad too real for my taste. This film puts human nature in your face, both for the better and worse. One of my favorite scenes in the film is when Kee is trapped in a immigrant building under seige by government troops. Once she gets to the ground floor and the first trooper sees her, there is an immediate cease fire, every one of them is shocked, with a confused and often blessed look in their eye. Based on PD James' novel this movie stars Clive Owen and the short lived Julianne Moore. Anything with Clive Owen serves as a hit for me, even King Arthur. The story takes place in a dystopian society where women are unable to become pregnant for unexplained reasons, but one can conclude it came as a result of man's mistake in one way or another that they have brought themselves or from a higher power. For example, the film's title is derived from Psalm 90:3: "Thou turnest man to destruction; and sayest, Return, ye children of men." The movie lightly graces us with the theories as to why this is happening but the fact of the matter is, and what makes the movie even more compelling is that it doesn't matter, or there are bigger issues at play. Not only are you caught asking other questions right away, waiting for their answer as you watch, but the smaller detailed questions overshadow the big picture which is what makes the film watchable again and again.

For example, instead of asking the obvious question as to why women cannot become pregnant, you are caught up in the ripples of its cause and start swimming in questions that cause the viewer to explore parallels in modern society. The film makes a strong statement in regards to the anti-immigration sentiment in modern societies like the UK and USA. Flocking to the UK because of the state that their own nations have come to, the immigrants in the film are marginalized, caged up, deported and even executed to express the chaos, disintegration of society and assimilation of a higher, more righteous race and/or nation.

The film's director took great care in placing subtle images from contemporary history and placed them into the film to prove that, though this is a fictional story, these monstrosities are indeed happening and have happened before our eyes. For example the director states:

"They exit the Russian apartments, and the next shot you see is this woman wailing, holding the body of her son in her arms. This was a reference to a real photograph of a woman holding the body of her son in the Balkans, crying with the corpse of her son. It's very obvious that when the photographer captured that photograph, he was referencing La Pieta, the Michelangelo sculpture of Mary holding the corpse of Jesus. So: We have a reference to something that really happened, in the Balkans, which is itself a reference to the Michelangelo sculpture. At the same time, we use the sculpture of David early on, which is also by Michelangelo, and we have of course the whole reference to the Nativity. And so everything was referencing and cross-referencing, as much as we could"

Specifically the director has provided multiple subtle references to the holocaust from the execution methods seen and used in the film to the scene where an elderly refugee woman speaking German is seen detained in a cage.

Despite the subtle contemporary parallels, the highly innovative single-shot action sequences are perhaps the most memorable parts of the direction of the film. It is incredible to see the main character, Theo run from the chaotic streets in the refugee camp as he is transporting Kee the pregnant girl to safety as they encounter a very realistic point of view. At one point Theo gets shot in the leg and blood spatters onto the screen. The splatter of blood does not leave the screen for a couple minutes after Theo is able to catch his breath. It gave me the sense that if I were there I would have blood on my face following Theo and wouldn't have the chance to wipe it off until the same moment that Theo has to catch his breath. This first person type of editing is also used in the audio as gunfire is shot near Theo and the chasing camera, so as a result the sound is very limited and ringing for a period of time it would take to recover your hearing after being so close to gunfire. This type of audio technique with gunfire is becoming popular and used in other movies as well, I love it.

The best part of the film in my opinion is when Theo is able to rescue Kee from a building facing gunfire as she is holding the baby she gave birth to the night earlier. The baby won't stop crying and as a result the mere sound of something that we can't stand to hear ironically becomes the sound that stops the gunfire and everyone suddenly tunes into. It is here that I believe everyone stops not only because they haven't heard the sound of a baby in decades but they wonder for a moment what they are even fighting for with the flicker of hope passing them in a baby's cry the hope leaves them as the baby gets carried out of sight and the fighting then continues.

The theme of hope is what I will conclude with. The film has been categorized as a modern-day Nativity story. The character of Kee represents Mary and Kee's pregnancy is revealed to Theo in a barn, alluding to the manger of the Nativity scene, and when other characters discover Kee and her baby, they respond with "Jesus Christ" or the sign of the cross, even going on their knees when they see it. Throughout the entire movie the main goal is to reach a meeting place of something called "the human project." Almost nothing is revealed about this organization except that it will bring not only salvation for our protagonists but to the entire earth. The human project then is the ultimate metaphor for hope, salvation and if you buy into the film being a modern day Nativity story, it is a metaphor for heaven which can be attained by humankind (to stretch the metaphor further) only with the sacrifice of the very human man Theo who sacrifices himself for mankind's salvation. The movie concludes with the sound of playing children which alludes to the hope that someday there will be children again.

You know that uncomfortable feeling that creeps up on you, when it occurs to you that something youre wearing is really inappropriate? Not like a boob tube is inappropriate (and they always are), but like tuxedo is for swimming, or socks are for sandals.

I was lengthening the garden behind the house a little while ago. Gaining an additional three feet of goldfish graveyard by clearing away reams of blackthorn from the hedge. Blackthorn is ferocious stuff, for a bush. After only a few minutes work, my shins looked like Amy Winehouse. All scratched up to bits. So you might think my inappropriate clothing choice for hedge-clearing was shorts. Not so.

I was wearing flip flops.

It transpired that flip flops were a pretty stupid thing to wear, once thorns started poking through into my feet and twigs attached themselves to the underneath, by stabbing.

It was this experience, as much as it was down to the directorial skills of Alfonso Cuarón, that captured me fully into the plight of Clive Owens character while I was watching Children of Men. IMDB summarises the film like this:

    In 2027, in a chaotic world in which humans can no longer procreate, a former activist agrees to help transport a miraculously pregnant woman to a sanctuary at sea, where her child's birth may help scientists save the future of humankind.

But its not the plot that made Children of Men so remarkable.

I should point out at this stage that I am not a fan of Clive Owen. He almost spoiled Sin City for me, and that was full of guns and Mickey Rourke, and prostitutes in their pants. Ive always thought Owen was just a bit dull, with a plain face and a forgettable demeanour. A bit tossy. And something about the back of his neck bothers me.

However, these qualities (except the neck thing) are intrinsic to why he works so well as the audiences focus during the course of the story. If were honest with ourselves, were all a bit dull, and if faced with true jeopardy we would all rather hide. Im not Bruce Willis, and neither are you. We are regular men and women in the street. Clive Owen isnt Bruce Willis either, and in the opening moments of the film Owen survives by literally being in the street, and not in the coffee shop shockingly blown up by terrorists.

This is the world of the movie, one in which society skates drearily about on the top of a deep pool of anarchy. With no children, and no perceived future, people have stopped bothering with tomorrow. Stopped bothering with one another. London of 2027 is populated by people forlornly killing time until it all just ends.

Owen is Theo Faron, a low-level civil servant office nobody. Like an arsey student, hes grown up and sold out to the man, getting on with trudging through life and dulled to the possibility of change. Keeping his head down to stay out of trouble.

But trouble finds him. Faron doesnt so much agree to transport a pregnant girl, as glumly realise that the caring father he used to be never went away. His ability to protect and help was only hidden under the years of drudge and hopelessness. Children of Men is a science fiction film on the ideas plane, an action film on the visual plane, and an exhaustingly fraught thriller all the way through.

I was amazed at the sheer battering my nerves suffered watching this. Cuaróns handling of action sequences is breathtaking. I suppose we should have guessed he had the right stuff when watching his grim version of Harry Potter. The violence of the film is depicted in a way that is so fresh and involving that my hands were sweating and my innards were thumping in my chest. My eyes copied Farons as he frantically scanned the scenery for any survivable options. Even more so than Saving Private Ryan, or A Very Long Engagement, or even Starship Troopers, the conflict sequences in this film cause you to truly question how anyone ever survives a sustained gun battle.

In two scenes you will wonder how the action seems so unremittingly intense, with barely a seconds room to catch your breath. Then you suss that theyre done in one shot. Or at least with invisibly hidden edits. One shot scenes, with tanks and motorbike crashes and bullet hits and explosions and complicated dialogue and Clive Owen running about in the murk looking like hes about to need a new pair of trousers.

Faron spends a large chunk of the events not quite ready for whats happening. He tumbles ineptly from one ambush to another, inadvertently tangled up in violence and double-crosses. He constantly wears the look of a man who knows that he doesnt really know whats going on. He bluffs his way to action hero status just by having quite good instincts to survive.

Even if he does steal the only car that wont start properly. Fails to get answers to important questions from dying friends. And discovers too late that hes the only one who came to war wearing flip flops.

Thats why I was inexorably drawn in. Because Clive Owen runs around dangerous places wearing flip flops and keeps hurting his foot.

And I can relate to that.

I slipped this movie back into its Netflix envelope tonight, weakly disappointed. 
Though well acted, designed well, and shot beautifully with an interesting and possibly original premise, the decrepit, rapid-fire world of coldly buried rage did not seem real. It could have been, but the meat of it was missing. There was no good, smiles,  brightness, explanation, personality, hope, or curiosity. Movies can be depressing and dismal BUT they must capture the human spirit, which is not one ichorous, somber shade of miserable gray. I don't think the entire human population except for about 10 peope would turn into monsters if the world went sour. Some would, of course, but think about yourseves and people you know. Would they all become evil gunslingers when thing got atrocious? No.  So I raised my eyebrows there and because of my disbelief, the film seemed strained and dishonest. Too much gunfire and bombs and not enough purpose. The minimal backstory failed to explain what I wanted to know, or at least flesh out this reality to make it more believable than just a dismal atmosphere (which was all the movie was until the end).
Children Of Men was "dark", yes, but for a film to be truly "dark" it must capture the dualities of light and dark that are the human race. THAT is when movies are great. Children Of Men was a mess to me, with no human qualities (except what nuggets are found in our protagonist, though they are unexplained and artless)or motive.
Though I had hoped to adore it as much as other futuristic/alternative reality/dramas, in the end I was as numb as the characters it contained. 2.5/5 stars.

Children of Men is an absoulutely superb futuristic sci-fi actioner by Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban director Alfonso Cuaron. This film provides a unique and breathtaking but nonetheless eye-opening dystopian vision of the world. Clive Owen does his usual one-noted shtick to perfection, which is perfect for his role as Theo. Julianne Moore makes a brief but memorable appearance, and Chiwetel Ejiofor is also great. Michael Caine is amusing and entertaining as the old hippie, but feels a tad out of place. Children of Men starts off relatively slow, allowing us to get our heads around the characters and the story. When the pace quickens though, it comes with such a jolt that it will take you a while to recover from it. Another outstanding action sequences is its sequence where Theo is making his way through all the battle fire, a scene that will pin you to your seat as well as take your breath away. Cuaron brings his jet black sense of humour to Children of Men, which some viewers may find off putting and out of place (eg. Michael Caine as a hippie), but it actually works really well. Children of Men was one of the most underrated films of 2006, yet, after Casino Royale, the best. It's absolutely appaling that people were spending money on absoulte tripe like Step Up and The Grudge 2 instead of spending it on this masterpiece. If you missed it, I have two things to say to you. You're an idiot, and see it now.

Alfonso Cuaron is a master director. He stages scenes in Children of Men as vivid and terrifying as any I've ever seen at the movies. A left of center vision of a truly awful future, it's based on P.D James' superb novel which interestingly if anything, felt a little right of center. The allusions to Christian theology will prove to be thought provoking for years to come, and the depiction of 2027 is so eerily plausible that when that year rolls around don't say that Cuaron didn't warn ya. This is a gloomy, extremely grim picture shot in somber grays (and a handful of startling single-shot takes) like guerilla journalism by cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki. The flaw is that Cuaron isn't as always as great staging scenes of dialogue between spectacular set pieces, but that's a small quibble in such a big, horrifying vision.

CHILDREN OF MEN is a riveting and bruising dysotopian thriller that takes the extremities of human extinction and finds disturbing realism in it.  The storyline for the film is well-wrought and endlessly engaging.  The actors themselves are outstanding; with Clive Owen, Julianne Moore, and Michael Caine as the big names in Alfonso Cauron's adaptation of the book that goes by the same name.  The real showstopper is newcomer Clare-Hope Ashitey hits strong emotional chords as Kee, the one hope the entire human race can based itself on.    

The premise is juicy: not one baby has been born in 18 years (since 2009), meaning the current year in the film is 2027.  All across the world, miscarraiges are taking place and a pill that puts you to sleep forever is very popular.  The world has lost hope for another baby, and that God has abandoned them from taking back the gift of life he gave in the beginning of mankind.  

As for the story, it ties together strong characters either compassionate, strong, and humane; or cruel, strong, and inhumane with timeless themes of betrayal, trust, and hope.  The two opposite sides of characters are both hopeful in their plans and relentless in putting them in motion.  Theo (Clive Owen) is basically the beacon of light that the right people could trust.  Everyone else does fall to the wayside in terms of being trustworthy (for their political and socio-economic plans or premature deaths).  

The acting could not have been better.  Clive Owen invests his whole being in his character Theo, underplaying his role as to gain sympathy for the shabby and emotionally deterred man before he finds his calling.  Clare-Hope Ashitey is incredible as Kee, as she does convey a down-to-earth sense of responsibity for her situation and character.  Chiewetel Ejifor (most recently in 2012) gives a deceptive and calm performance as a member of a "terrorist" group, whose intentions are big for Kee.  Michael Caine and Julianne Moore do their usual best as the former is a pot-smoking, genial aging man, and the latter is the energetic leader of the "terrorist" group.  

Director Alfonso Cauron has crafted a thrilling and bold dysotopian masterpiece with all the greatness that the best can do.  His use of long shots and close-ups show the up-close disconnection the characters feel towards their crumbling world.  The startling moments of violence are just that, as the dire situations call for violence to be done.  His most striking feature he added to the film is how relatable the dying world is to our own, only that women now can still concieve.  

A juicy premise, strong characters tied together with the timeless themes of betrayal, trust, and hope, top-notch acting, masterful directing, and the film's relatability to our world makes CHILDREN OF MEN a riveting, bruising and thrilling dysotopian masterpiece.
